results.title: Stalag 17
results.brief_description: Set in a German prisoner-of-war camp, “Stalag 17” is about a group of American sergeants confined to one barrack, trying to survive wartime restrictions and spartan conditions. Amid the soldiers is one man, Sefton, a canny operator and racketeer who has amassed a case of contraband that enables him to bribe favours, providing him with more comfortable surrounds. When a meticulously planned escape is expertly foiled, the men suspect a traitor within the ranks; soon all suspicions turn to Sefton, whose compassion has been battered out of him after years as a POW, but could he be a Nazi collaborator? Effectively utilising the confines of the barrack as an incendiary setting for pent up frustrations, Wilder successfully explores the mob mentality in a compelling manner; less compelling (at least dramatically) are the humorous moments operating as light relief which stagnate the drama, diluting the well crafted tension. “Stalag 17” was one of the first films to convey war with humour - a definite precursor to “MASH”, “Catch-22” and the campy outlandishness of “Hogan’s Heroes”. William Holden won an Academy Award for his portrayal of the embittered Sefton - a role he apparently reluctantly played. Cast includes Don Taylor, Otto Preminger, Robert Strauss, Harvey Lembeck, Peter Graves, Richard Erdman, Sig Rumann and Neville Brand.

results.title: Napoleon
results.creator_credit: Abel Gance, Films Historiques and Societe Generale Des Films
results.brief_description: This epic historical bio-pic, filmed in 1925, was planned as one of several portraying the life of French war hero Napoleon Bonaparte. This instalment, the only one made, traces the story of Napoleon’s school days, his flight from Corsica, through the French Revolution and the Terror, his romance with Josephine, culminating in his triumphant invasion of Italy in 1797. Gance’s initial version (reputedly five hours plus) was severely edited and numerous versions were released over the years, none of which were attuned to Gance’s vision; this version, a painstaking restoration, comes closest. What has excited film buffs about this film is Gance’s revolutionary use of film techniques - colour tinting, swish pans, handheld shots, lengthy double exposures, and split screens culminating in a twenty-minute triptych sequence, which alternates widescreen panoramas with complex multiple-image montages projected simultaneously on three screens. The film, which is overwhelmingly patriotic, has grandeur worthy of D.W. Griffith; the cast are in the thousands and the set pieces are enormous; the panoramic shots, in particular those projected by three separate reels are stunning. However the score, by Francis Ford Coppola’s father Carmine, is militaristic and fairly insipid, and may grate on some viewers. With English intertitles.

results.title: Walker
results.creator_credit: Alex Cox, Lorenzo O'Brien, Angel Flores Marini, ICINE and Walker Films Limited
results.brief_description: William Walker, and his belief in manifest destiny - the American practice of continental expansion - are at the core of Alex Cox’s satire of a 19th century American legend. A gang of incompetent American troops, led by Walker, head south from San Francisco to liberate Nicaragua from its oppressive president. Corneilius Vanderbuilt, a tycoon millionaire, funds the mission, but feels Walker’s naive, albeit charismatic, character will ensure stability in the Central American state controlling the Pacific-Atlantic trade. Walker embodies the religious and puritanical traits of manifest destiny and is filled with notions of self-importance and historical greatness. Walker is oblivious to the barbarity of his own troops and their thirst for sex and violence; ironically the behaviour of his men epitomizes the false image that Walker holds of the savages. When Nicaragua is won Walker places a patriot as President; he appoints himself General of the armed forces and, in an act that summarizes the history of the South America, stages a coup against his own government. Dreamlike scenes of slow-motion bloody violence are complimented by Ed Harris’ ability to shift between dry deadpan humour and frenzied evangelical prophesising. Melding past and future images of soldiers, Cox presents a powerful non-linear twist on history, suggesting a potent link between manifest destiny and Reaganism. Cast includes Richard Masur, Rene Assa, Rene Auberjonois, Peter Boyle.

results.title: An Egyptian story = Hadota Misreya
results.creator_credit: Youssef Chahine and Misr International Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Alexandria Trilogy”.
This unusual and fascinating follow-up to “Alexandria, why?” picks up the story of Yehia, the troubled adolescent boy headed for prosperity in America as WWII ravaged his Egyptian homeland. Yehia, now a draconian film director who neglects his wife and children in order to create his work, falls ill and requires open-heart surgery. During the operation a young boy, representing Yehia’s conscience, accuses him of betraying his ideals. A metamorphic trial ensues in which various witnesses, including family and colleagues, offer their testimony about “the defendant”. These proceedings force the filmmaker to come to terms with hidden emotions involving his life, work and country. Chahine’s work examines the politics of the 1952 revolution and its demise in 1967, as well as the frissons that arise as he tries to reconcile his art with his ambitions. This film recalls “Eight and a half” and “All that jazz” in that it examines one man’s conscience and history, in a humoristic, satirical and at times, surrealistic, manner. This sequel was followed up by “Alexandria again and forever”. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Alexandria again and forever
results.creator_credit: Youssef Chahine, Le Sept, Paris Classics and Misr International Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alexandria Trilogy”.
In this third and final instalment of Youssef Chahine’s “Alexandria” trilogy (preceded by Alexandria, why? and An Egyptian story) Chahine’s protagonist and alter-ego, Yehia, is now an aging filmmaker who laments the state of the Egyptian film industry and joins his colleagues on strike to protest their circumstances. Simultaneously Yehia (played by the director himself) finds himself attracted to two actors - the handsome young Amr, who Yehia works with on laboured productions, and Nadia, with whom he hopes to collaborate. Following on from the themes explored in “An Egyptian story”, Yahia heartlessly forfeits his personal relationships in favour of his work. Yahine’s struggle to reconcile his art with his ambitions and personal failings is set against Egypt’s divisive drive, in the 1980s, toward democratic reform. The film takes on a surreal flavour with several musical interludes (one delightfully recalling “Singin’ in the rain” as Yehia and Amr celebrate winning the Silver Bear award at Berlin). Chahine applies his signature energy to the film - an appealing mix of whimsy, satire and barbed attacks on the political and social situation in his beloved homeland. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Cairo station = Bab el hadid
results.brief_description: Renowned Egyptian director Youssef Chahine established his international reputation with “Cairo Station” after it screened at the Berlin Film Festival. Focusing on a group of marginalised luggage carriers and soft-drink sellers who live in abandoned traincars, Chahine posits Cairo’s main railroad station as a microcosm of Egyptian society. A crippled newspaper dealer (played powerfully by Chahine himself), falls in love with a beautiful but indifferent lemonade seller who is engaged to the muscular and virile leader of the luggage-carriers. Swept away by his obsessive desire, the crippled man kidnaps the object of his passion, with terrible consequences. Into this story of doomed sexual obsession amongst a shadowy underclass, Chahine weaves glaring economic disparity, union activity, and other politically charged motifs. The work of Fritz Lang and the genres of film-noir and neo-realism are often cited as influences on the film. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: The Marriage of the blessed = Arusi-ye khuban [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Mohsen Makhmalbaf and Farabi Cinema Foundation
results.brief_description: This is an extremely confronting and at times disturbing film exploring the psychological torture of a shell-shocked war photojournalist and his attempts to come to grips with reality on returning home from the Iran-Iraq war front. After spending some time rehabilitating in a hospital mental asylum in Tehran, Haji (Mahmud Bigham) is finally released to the care of his fiancee Mehri (Roya Nonahali) and her family. However Haji is continually haunted with images of war and daily life becomes a struggle sending Haji into a downward spiral emotionally and psychologically. Mehri, who shares Haji’s passion for photography, tries in her own way to assist Haji in his recovery surrounding him with positive images of life whilst also pushing for their wedding ceremony to take place against her family’s wishes who now want to cancel the marriage. When Haji is given back his old job at the local newspaper, both he and Mehri take to the streets of Tehran with their cameras capturing images of the homeless, the drug addicts and prostitutes, and the oppressive poverty that exists post-revolution Iran. Haji’s boss, however, is not interested in social issues and refuses to print the photos leading to a tragic sequence of events for Haji and Mehri, and Haji’s eventual breakdown. Using evocative sounds and images, Makhmalbaf (Kandahar, Gabbeh) has created an amazing piece of experimental and controversial filmmaking in “The Marriage of the blessed” which for all its political and social commentary, managed to escape the religious censorship by the Iranian regime of the time. Cast includes Mohsen Zehtab, Ebrahim Abadi, Hossein Moslemi with cinemaphotography by Ali Reza Zarindest. In Farsi with English subtitles. NOTE: Contains disturbing war images.

Haji’s boss, however, is not interested in social issues and refuses to print the photos leading to a tragic sequence of events for Haji and Mehri, and Haji’s eventual breakdown. Using evocative sounds and images, Makhmalbaf (Kandahar, Gabbeh) has created an amazing piece of experimental and controversial filmmaking in “The Marriage of the blessed” which for all its political and social commentary, managed to escape the religious censorship by the Iranian regime of the time. Cast includes Mohsen Zehtab, Ebrahim Abadi, Hossein Moslemi with cinemaphotography by Ali Reza Zarindest. In Farsi with English subtitles. NOTE: Contains disturbing war images.

results.title: Persona = Diabolic women = Masks [DVD]
results.brief_description: An actress’s nervous breakdown occasions her deliberate withdrawal into speechlessness. As a consequence she appears to break down her nurse’s confident personality. However, “Persona” cannot be summarised in terms of conventional plot. It is a virtual monologue in which language is presented as fraudulent. In Susan Sontag’s words, it is “a powerful instance of the motif of exchange. The actress creates a void by her silence. The nurse, by speaking, falls into it.” It is possible to interpret the first half of the film as naturalistic drama but following the disruption of the ‘terrifying caesura’ in the middle (which, like the opening, operates on the principle of intensity, not Brechtian detachment), the level of reality of each event is ambiguous, unresolved. Cast includes: Bibi Andersson, Liv Ullmann, Gunnar Bjornstrand. Photography by Sven Nykvist. In Swedish with English subtitles.

results.title: Female vampire = La Comtesse noire [DVD] (E)
results.creator_credit: Jesus Franco, Marius Lesoeur, Films Marc and Brux International Picture
results.brief_description: This influential erotic horror film, directed by Jesus Franco, established the reputation of erotic actress and horror icon, Lina Romay. In this unabashed performance she plays Countess Iriana of Karlstein, a mute vampire who resides on a remote island, feeding off men and women to satiate her desire to literally suck the life out of her lovers. Iriana faces a new challenge when she meets a poet who believes himself destined to become her lover and, like her, immortal. Simultaneously a scientist Dr. Roberts and his colleague, Dr. Orlof, become aware that a vampire is at work and set about finding him or her. “Female vampire” has a dream-like quality, and similar to “Vampyros Lesbos”, has achieved cult status amid horror buffs. Various cuts of this film exist; this version favours the sexuality of the characters over the more graphic horror elements. The deleted scenes in special features contains scenes of a more bloody nature. Features excessive nudity, and scenes of masturbation and oral sex that are quite explicit. Cast includes Jack Taylor, Alice Arno, Monica Swinn. This film is also known under the following titles: Bare Breasted Countess, Erotikill, Erotikiller and The Loves of Irina. Please note, this is the dubbed English language version.

results.title: Irreversible [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Gaspar Noe, Christophe Rossignon, Studio Canal and 120 Films
results.brief_description: Gaspar Noe’s “Irreversible” made its notorious debut at the 2002 Cannes film festival where it provoked extreme reactions from audiences. Subsequently it has been dubbed as the film with the most walkouts. Noe’s previous feature, “I stand alone” was considered at the time as an uncompromising and shocking film which presented a bleak and nihilistic view of humanity. Noe even included a foreboding warning to viewers to exit the cinema before its shocking climax, a claim that was no mere cheap effect. With “Irreversible” (which includes a brief cameo from the lead character of “I stand alone”) Noe has upped the ante to an intense degree, making this one of the more distressing films you are likely to experience. Taking the very well used genre of the revenge film as a starting point, Noe defies expectations and delivers a remarkable aural and visual assault on the senses. Using mainly improvised dialogue, a disorientating camera style and depicting the film’s events backwards, “Irreversible” goes from an intense act of violence, to a horrendous rape (which plays out in excruciating real time) and finally to a quiet contemplative moment. The film’s peaceful coda leaves a bitter and devastating aftertaste as we are left to ponder the film’s final words, ‘time destroys everything’. Please note: contains scenes of violence which may disturb some viewers, and depicts explicit sexual relationships. Cast includes: Albert Dupontel, Jo Prestia.
